ROLE: Neuro-UX knowledge base for visual and interaction decisions
DESCRIPTION: Central library of perception, attention and decision-making principles for designing high-conversion, low-friction eCommerce experiences.

proximity.summary: Elements that are close together are perceived as a group.
ux_application: Group price, title and CTA together.
Keep filters and their labels visually tight.
Avoid large gaps between logically related elements.
risks: Too much spacing breaks perceived grouping.

similarity.summary: Elements that look similar are perceived as related.
ux_application: Use consistent button styles for similar actions.
Use one style for 'primary actions', another for 'secondary'.
risks: Making destructive actions look like primary.
Too many button styles dilute meaning.

figure_ground.summary: Users distinguish a focal element (figure) from the background (ground).
ux_application: Use contrast and depth to highlight primary content.
Dim background when overlays or drawers are open.
risks: Low contrast between content and background.
Busy backgrounds behind text or CTAs.

continuity.summary: The eye follows lines, curves and flows in a preferred direction.
ux_application: Guide users with clear reading flows (Z/F patterns).
Align price, variant selector and CTA in a vertical flow.

closure.summary: The brain tends to fill in missing information to see complete shapes.
ux_application: Use simple, complete shapes for icons and badges.

fitts_law.summary: Time to acquire a target depends on its size and distance.
rules: Primary CTAs must be large enough and close to the point of decision.
On mobile, avoid placing critical CTAs in hard-to-reach corners.

hicks_law.summary: Decision time increases with the number and complexity of choices.
rules: Use progressive disclosure (more details on demand).
risks: Exposing all filter options by default.
Long CTA groups with similar labels.

serial_position_effect.summary: Users remember best the first and last items in a sequence.
rules: Place most important links at the beginning or end of navigation.
In lists, prioritize high-value items first.

guidelines: Align headline, key benefit and CTA following F/Z flows.
Avoid breaking reading flow with random element placement.

COGNITIVE_LOAD.definition: Cognitive load is the mental effort required to understand and act.
principles: Use plain language and clear hierarchy.
symptoms_of_overload: Users scrolling up and down repeatedly.
reduction_strategies: Offer sensible presets instead of raw controls.

PRE_ATTENTIVE_FEATURES.summary: Certain visual properties are processed by the brain before conscious attention.
ux_rules: Use one primary highlight color for key CTAs.
Use subtle motion for state changes, not decoration.
Do not overload the interface with multiple competing signals.

integration_with_color_module.goal: Align pre-attentive signals with emotional and conversion goals.

WEBER_LAW_AND_CONTRAST.summary: Perceived change depends on relative, not absolute, difference.
applications: Small contrast changes may be ignored by users.
Price changes must be visually obvious if important.
Discount labels should have a clear contrast against surroundings.

guidelines: Line length: 45–75 characters for comfortable reading.
Avoid using more than 2–3 font families.
Use hierarchy via size/weight, not random colors.

DECISION_ARCHITECTURE.summary: Structuring choices to support good decisions without manipulation.

patterns.description: Pre-select the most common or recommended option when ethically safe.
Hide secondary options behind toggles or accordions.
